history.content:
I think most CS clubs have wrapped up recruiting by now, but there might still be some community service ones you can get into that involve teaching CS to high school/middle school students in the Bay Area (something like PiE). I'm personally not in any of these clubs, so I can't say for sure though.

As you take more courses getting into these clubs will be much easier, so I wouldn't worry too much about it :)

children.subject:
What you get out from the CSUA really is how much you put in. If you're willing to stick around the office more (311 Soda!), hang around, attend our weekly PB/Officer meetings (open to the public, but we don't exactly advertise this, other than inside the office), get in touch with the people that you see over and over in the office - you'll see that it's quite an inclusive space, and it can be your second family.

Of course, if you don't come around much, just pop by the office to buy some snacks, and simply attend our events when they come around, you won't get much from the CSUA. As with pretty much other club, you get what you put in.

Feel free to email me (yitzdeng@berkeley.edu) if you have any more questions! I'd love to hear any more concerns you have and see if we can address those issues.

Hey! I'm from Pioneers in Engineering (PiE), the organization mentioned in the student organization! We are definitely still accepting members, and we don't require any experience coming in. If you're interested in getting involved with a project you don't have experience in, we 100% will work with you to teach you what you need to be successful! In fact, a lot of the things we work on don't use things specifically taught in classes anyway.

You can read more about our organization here, https://pioneers.berkeley.edu or email recruiting@pioneers.berkeley.edu with any questions. 

Specifically, I might point out https://pioneers.berkeley.edu/get-involved/projects.html, which lists all the projects we're working on in the next year. We're a nonprofit that hosts a robotics competition for local high school students, so there's definitely some unique stuff we're working on (none of which requires prior experience!).

There's also AUV's @ Berkeley which is an underwater robotics club. It's a brand new club (2nd year) so there's plenty of opportunities to grow individually and as a team. Since it's a smaller club each individual's impact is much greater and you can also get the chance to become a leader. Weekly meetings are on Thursdays from 7-9 pm in Jacobs 220. Anyone interested, feel free to stop by! We welcome people of all majors and experience levels :)

history.content:
Hi. I was wondering if there were any CS student organizations that were welcoming toward new CS students (as in students with no previous CS experience.) 

Maybe it's too late for this semester (let me know if it isn't though!), but I'm looking for a CS student organization that I can learn new things from, work on projects with, and form a community/ second family with. I wish to get more exposure to the CS field, but it seems paradoxical that I need experience to get experience even to just join a club.

I've tried applying to things like Mobile Developers and Blueprint, but I was unable to get in because of my lack of CS experience. 

I am a part of CSUA, but the organization is so big that it really doesn't feel like I am part of the organization. It doesn't host meetings regularly and just hosts events that anyone can attend. 

Do you guys know of any CS student organizations that would fit this criteria?

Thanks!
history.subject: CS Student Organizations that welcome beginners
